source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk2
evidence_span: Slip is assumed to occur on the six prism systems of the type (1010) <1210) and the 24 pyramidal systems of the type (1011) <2113)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk2
evidence_span: Basal slip is not considered to be important in zirconium alloys [19,20] and has been observed only at high temperatures [21]

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk3
evidence_span: For the elastic constants, and their temperature dependence, the values of Fisher and Renken [22] for crystal bar $\mathbf { Z r }$ will be used.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk3
evidence_span: Thermal expansion coefficients are taken from recent work by MacEwen and Faber [23], who used neutron diffraction to determine residual thermal strains in Zircaloy-2 rod. In the basal plane, the thermal expansion is isotropic; $\alpha _ { 1 } = \alpha _ { 2 } = 5 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { K } ^ { - 1 }$ Normal to the basal plane $\alpha _ { 3 } = 1 1 . 4 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { K } ^ { - 1 }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk3
evidence_span: Thermal expansion coefficients are taken from recent work by MacEwen and Faber [23], who used neutron diffraction to determine residual thermal strains in Zircaloy-2 rod. In the basal plane, the thermal expansion is isotropic; $\alpha _ { 1 } = \alpha _ { 2 } = 5 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { K } ^ { - 1 }$ Normal to the basal plane $\alpha _ { 3 } = 1 1 . 4 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { K } ^ { - 1 }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk3
evidence_span: It is assumed that prism shear hardens both the prism and pyramidal systems at a rate of $4 0 0 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ , while pyramidal shear hardens both slip systems at a rate of ${ \bf 8 0 0 \ M P a }$ .

evidence_span: It is assumed that prism shear hardens both the prism and pyramidal systems at a rate of $4 0 0 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ , while pyramidal shear hardens both slip systems at a rate of ${ \bf 8 0 0 \ M P a }$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk3
evidence_span: Figure 1 shows the basal pole figure, obtained by neutron diffraction at the NRU reactor at Chalk River, Ontario, for Zircaloy-2 rod; the texture is nearly perfectly axisymmetrical, and roughly $80 \%$ of the grains have their $\langle c \rangle$ poles within $1 5 ^ { \circ }$ of perpendicular to the axis of the rod.

evidence_span: the neutron diffraction lines sharpen by as much as a factor of two during the first $2 . 5 \%$ compressive strain after $4 \%$ tensile deformation

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
evidence_span: Many of the features of the deformation of Zircaloy-2, including the strength differential, the initial workhardening rates in tension and compression, and the Bauschinger effect are direct consequences of the residual stresses produced by anisotropic thermal expansion and plastic flow.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
evidence_span: Many of the features of the deformation of Zircaloy-2, including the strength differential, the initial workhardening rates in tension and compression, and the Bauschinger effect are direct consequences of the residual stresses produced by anisotropic thermal expansion and plastic flow.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
evidence_span: Many of the features of the deformation of Zircaloy-2, including the strength differential, the initial workhardening rates in tension and compression, and the Bauschinger effect are direct consequences of the residual stresses produced by anisotropic thermal expansion and plastic flow.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
evidence_span: The evolution of residual strain, from the initial state resulting from cooling to a final state after various amounts of tensile deformation, is in good agreement with direct measurements made using neutron diffraction, provided the comparison is made on the basis of the increase in flow stress past the proportional limit.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
evidence_span: The underprediction of the plastic strain required to reach the fully plastic state in all grains is a consequence of the Taylor assumption that the strain in each grain is the same as in the body as a whole.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: In rod-textured Zircaloy-2, deformed at room temperature in uniaxial tension or compression, we observe the following. In tension, for strains less than $4 \%$ , there are no twins at all.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: In compression, we see twinning by $4 \%$ strain, but the volume fraction is very low, about 2 to $3 \%$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: For the as-rolled and stress-relieved tubes, the $f .$ -factors were strongly influenced by the reduction in area as well as the $\boldsymbol { Q }$ -value during final cold work.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: As the reduction in area increased under the same $\pmb { Q }$ -value, the $f _ { r }$ -factor decreased.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: When these tubes were recrystallized, tubes with lower reduction had little change in texture and tubes with higher reduction showed greater change.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: Thus texture was independent of reduction in area in the case of recrystallized tubes.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: The relation between reduction and CSR showed the same tendency as the above relation between reduction and $f _ { r }$ -factor.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: The tool design had a significant effect on the deformation texture.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: The experimental data for the $f$ factors correlated fairly well with that calculated on the basis of the theory that the texture is determined by the local strain ratio.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: The mechanical and physical properties of Zircaloy tubing are strongly influenced by crystallographic anisotropy that is formed during cold work.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk8
evidence_span: The effect of cold-work parameters on the $f$ factor $[ I ]$ and the contractile strain ratio was investigated using Zircaloy tubes fabricated by different processes including the high reduction process of $91 \%$
